DataElement.preferredName: Lesion Measurement Source Diagnostic Imaging Modality Name
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The text describes the imaging modality source used for lesion measurement.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Positron Emission Tomography and Computed Tomography Scan

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Positron Emission Tomography and Computed Tomography Scan
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An imaging technique that utilizes positron emission tomography and computed tomography in a single machine.

Concepts.longName: Positron Emission Tomography and Computed Tomography Scan
Concepts.definition: An imaging technique that utilizes positron emission tomography and computed tomography in a single machine.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

Concepts.definition: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 2023.3.21 Alt VM added per ticket request CADSR0002164. ak

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Examination of the tissues and deep structures of the body by x-ray, using the fluoroscope, a device that produces an image when x-rays strike a fluorescent screen.

Concepts.definition: Examination of the tissues and deep structures of the body by x-ray, using the fluoroscope, a device that produces an image when x-rays strike a fluorescent screen.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of high-energy radiation.  In low doses, x-rays are used to diagnose diseases by making pictures of the inside of the body.  In high doses, x-rays are used to treat cancer.

Concepts.definition: Ionizing electromagnetic radiation having a wavelength that is shorter than ultraviolet radiation and longer than gamma radiation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Concepts.definition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: High frequency sound, generally with a frequency greater than 20,000 Hz.

Concepts.definition: High frequency sound, generally with a frequency greater than 20,000 Hz.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Events, people, materials and activities uniquely defined by medical imaging.
ConceptualDomain.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine
